newsitem.title: GERMANY: Waigel says France, Germany committed to EMU.
newsitem.headline: Waigel says France, Germany committed to EMU.

text.p: German Finance Minister Theo Waigel said France and Germany reafffirmed on Tuesday their commitment to keep up efforts to cut government spending in order to meet criteria for European currency union.

Waigel also said after the meeting of top financial officials that both countries believed a stability pact to ensure fiscal discipline after currency union was essential for gaining public confidence in the new currency.
Despite the positive developments in the second quarter, Waigel said Germany will "do all things necessary" to meet the Maastricht Treaty's strict criteria for currency union.

The treaty, which sets goals on interest and exchange rates, inflation and public budgets, calls for nations wanting to join currency union to have deficits of no more than three percent of gross domestic product (GDP) in 1997.
Waigel said that Germany re-emphasised during the meeting that it would keep striving to get its budget deficit below three percent in 1997 with its cost-cutting policies.

Waigel made the comments at a news conference following a meeting, which included Waigel, Bundesbank President Hans Tietmeyer, French Finance Minister Jean Arthuis and Bank of France President Jean-Claude Trichet.

The meeting, sandwiched between critical budget talks in Bonn and Paris this week, falls just three days ahead of an informal meeting of European Union finance officials in Dublin which will address key aspects of the single currency project.
